qas.question: Which two browsers promised to develop Metro-style versions of their browsers?
What does Chromes version for Windows 8 do?

answers.text: uses a full-screen version of the existing desktop interface

qas.question: What does Firefox's version for Windows 8 do?
When was Firefox's version of Windows 8 made accesible?
Which three browsers promised to develop Metro-style versions of their browsers?

plausible_answers.text: uses a full-screen version of the existing desktop interface

qas.question: What doesn't Chromes version for Windows 8 do?

plausible_answers.text: uses a full-screen version of the existing desktop interface

qas.question: What does Chromes version for Windows 9 do?
What does Firefox's version for Windows 9 do?
When was Firefox's version of Windows 9 made accesible?

context: The developers of both <a0_0><b4_0>Chrome and Firefox<b4_0/><a0_0/> committed to developing Metro-style versions of their browsers; while Chrome's "Windows 8 mode" <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>uses a full-screen version of the existing desktop interface<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, Firefox's version (which was first made available on the "Aurora" release channel in <a3_0><b8_0>September 2013<b8_0/><a3_0/>) <a2_0><b7_0>uses a touch-optimized interface<b7_0/><a2_0/> inspired by the Android version of Firefox. In October 2013, Chrome's app was changed to mimic the desktop environment used by Chrome OS. Development of the Firefox app for Windows 8 has since been cancelled, citing a lack of user adoption for the beta versions.
